author: axic3354
content: The set schedule was attempted during 2019 and the devcon names originated from there to avoid arguing about names.  It did not come to fruition though, because of the reliance on core teams to prove EIPs are safe (basically to do at least 50% of the work on EIPs, as opposed to the champion). Hence the idea came up to have an "EIP-centric roadmap", where EIP champions are supposed to do >90% of the work, which I think we are getting closer now, but still not there yet.

author: ajsutton
content:
I wonder how many improvements could be added one side at a time even when they need to work together. 
As a straw man example, the beacon chain could start exposing withdrawal information as part of the execution context which would just be ignored by the execution clients. Then when the execution side upgrades it starts actually using those to do the withdrawal. Won‚Äôt be possible with everything but would be a very useful pattern to keep consensus and execution loosely coupled.

author: dirigible6945
content:
Hello everyone and I hope you're all well. I was told on Twitter to speak here if I wanted to chime in on the London/Ropsten issue. I'm only a small ETH dev but I wanted to voice my concerns.

Does this not have echoes of Berlin? We delayed that fork once and when it eventually went live it hit a consensus problem, resulting in exchange and transaction halting. Huge and scary!

Seems to me when you discover a bug in testnet, there is value in examining code correctness overall of a major project to find out if it there aren't other problems. The amazing thing about this bug is how late it was found in testnet despite, presumably, being present for several weeks through Goerli and Rinkeby. I'm only a small chain developer so I do not know the value of my word, but caution seems prudent to avoid errors here?

<@456226577798135808> comment about prior rules in ETH about testnet issues generating immediate waits is salient, so my anticipation was this would be the same here. 

Regardless a decision would need to be made very soon here about whether to  go live or to run on testnets longer for 1~2 weeks. I'd implore ACD to give it some serious consideration.

author: timbeiko
content: On this last point, I feel like there is no easy answer: on one hand, client devs *are* the ones who need to make this call (they have merge access to the clients üôÇ ), but OTOH, it is ‚Äúhigh risk / low reward‚Äù to be the one dissenting voice. It doesn‚Äôt help that the calls are public and so people need to be very careful about how they phrase things or risk backlash (as we‚Äôve seen before). Perhaps one solution is to have some venue which isn‚Äôt fully public (e.g. Chatham House Rules), and just a summary afterwards ? I‚Äôm also happy to book 1:1 calls with all teams, but this doesn‚Äôt help in cases, like this one I believe, where back and forth may be required.
